title: Diploma in Dog Grooming
headline: Learn the theory and practice of dog grooming in this free online diploma course that qualifies you as a professional.
description: This diploma course introduces you to pet grooming and explains why it is necessary. We demonstrate the importance of staying calm and assertive when dealing with dogs. The course then examines canine anatomy and shows you how to protect the dogs in your care. We lay out the steps of the pre-grooming health check and establish why it is vital that your client knows its results. We also break down how to start your own pet-grooming business.
courseDescription:
Pets are an essential part of many people’s lives. When treated with affection, they become constant companions who return that love. This course provides a comprehensive introduction to dog grooming, including its history and an analysis of canine anatomy and health.

Parasites, infections and zoonotic diseases can affect dogs and pre-grooming health assessments help to identify coat or skin disorders. We present a series of lessons and demonstrations to teach you how to groom a dog effectively. We explain how to deal with difficult dogs and manage their training to keep your service running smoothly. You will learn how to safely bathe, wash and dry a dog to leave it clean and fluffy.

The course then shows you how to launch your own dog-grooming business to help you monetize your new skill. We identify various laws and procedures to consider when serving clients. Dog grooming can present wonderful opportunities and is a great career move. This diploma course suits those who want to learn more about caring for dogs, either their own or professionally.

Start Course Now
certificateDetail:
All Alison courses are free to enrol study and complete. To successfully complete this course and become an Alison Graduate, you need to achieve 80% or higher in each course assessment. Once you have completed this course, you have the option to acquire an official Diploma, which is a great way to share your achievement with the world.

Your Alison is:
  • Ideal for sharing with potential employers
  • Include it in your CV, professional social media profiles and job applications.
  • An indication of your commitment to continuously learn, upskill & achieve high results.
  • An incentive for you to continue empowering yourself through lifelong learning.
Alison offers 3 types of Diplomas for completed Diploma courses:
  • Digital : a downloadable in PDF format immediately available to you when you complete your purchase.
  • : a physical version of your officially branded and security-marked , posted to you with FREE shipping.
  • Framed : a physical version of your officially branded and security marked in a stylish frame, posted to you with FREE shipping.

All are available to purchase through the Alison Shop. For more information on purchasing Alison , please visit our FAQs. If you decide not to purchase your Alison , you can still demonstrate your achievement by sharing your Learner Record or Learner Achievement Verification, both of which are accessible from your Dashboard. For more details on our pricing, please visit our Pricing Page

• Introduction to Dog Grooming

  • After completing this module you will be able to:
    • Introduce pet grooming and why it is so necessary
    • Explain why we need to be calm and assertive when dealing with dogs
    • Understand the types of people that make the best pet groomers
    • Detail the equipment required
    • Highlight the importance of safety in the workplace
    • Discuss various diseases associated with dogs

  • Pets are an essential part of many people’s lives.

  • When treated with love and affection, they respond by being constant companions who are always ready to return the affection they are shown. Owning a pet, particularly a dog, has many proven psychological and physical health benefits. One of the main reasons for these therapeutic benefits are that humans have an ingrained need for communication through touch. Snuggling up to a pet fulfils a fundamental need in us which many people may otherwise, be denied.

    • This will make it easier to understand why they may not be keen on the grooming process and what can be done to change the experience for them.

      Because grooming needs to be a regular feature of a dog’s life, it needs to be as unthreatening and as enjoyable as possible.

      If your dog loves bath time and regular grooming, then you are doing something right. Learning about the grooming process in greater detail will ensure that everything is being done as well as it can be.

    • One of the main reasons that dogs dislike bathing is that they see the process as threatening. Because the process was not done correctly the first time, the dog registered the process as distinctly unpleasant. The next time they were bathed, they tried to avoid it and a tussle ensued, which served to cement the idea that bath time was a thing to be avoided at all costs.

      One of the main reasons that dogs dislike bathing is that they see the process as threatening. Because the process was not done correctly the first time, the dog registered the process as distinctly unpleasant. The next time they were bathed, they tried to avoid it and a tussle ensued, which served to cement the idea that bath time was a thing to be avoided at all costs.
    • Look at the process from the dog’s point of view: I’m lying quietly in the sun and my owner comes up to me, full of tension, and I know it’s bath time again. I am now totally tense and needing to be out of here as fast as possible. My owner wrestles me to a standstill and then drags me off to the bath tub. Now I’m required to get into cold water and be soaked to the skin. Towards the end of the process, I will have water and soap running into my eyes and ears and getting up my nose. Then comes the rinse with the cold hose pipe – a jet of freezing water all over my body and face. After that, I will be left outside until I’m dry enough to not wet the furniture.

    • DOG'S POV
      Look at the process from the dog’s point of view: I’m lying quietly in the sun and my owner comes up to me, full of tension, and I know it’s bath time again. I am now totally tense and needing to be out of here as fast as possible. My owner wrestles me to a standstill and then drags me off to the bath tub. Now I’m required to get into cold water and be soaked to the skin. Towards the end of the process, I will have water and soap running into my eyes and ears and getting up my nose.   • Introduction to Dog Grooming: Summary

  • Pet grooming is a viable career choice, particularly for people who love animals and have an eye for detail. 

    There is a lot to learn about handling and management of dogs. While some dogs love the grooming experience, there are others that see it as a highly stressful experience. 

    These dogs can learn that grooming is a good experience if the groomer has the right skills. 

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • While it is associated with pet care, dog grooming, on a professional level, involves the use of industrial premises and equipment which are inherently hazardous. If not properly equipped, managed, and maintained, a pet grooming premises could become a highly dangerous environment.

  • History of Dog Grooming

  • After completing this module you will be able to:
    • Explain humans' historic relationship with dogs
    • Detail how dog grooming developed
    • Describe the very first dog grooming businesses
    • Point out what first sparked the advent of the modern dog parlour
    • Understand why formal qualifications in the industry are required

    • It went on to become popular in other parts of Europe and England.

      While grooming grew in popularity, it must have been done by the dogs’ owners. It was only in the mid-1800s that dog grooming seems to have started developing into a business with street vendors offering dog shaving services on the streets of Paris and Rome.

      By the end of the 1800s the art of grooming had blossomed into a viable business.
      It went on to become popular in other parts of Europe and England.

      While grooming grew in popularity, it must have been done by the dogs’ owners. It was only in the mid-1800s that dog grooming seems to have started developing into a business with street vendors offering dog shaving services on the streets of Paris and Rome.

      Customer ID
      Customer Name
    • In 1900, an article entitled “A Dogs’ Toilet Club” was featured in The Royal Magazine.

      The article presents what looks like a highly organised business with all the tools and equipment one could want for such a business in those times.

      The Dogs’ Toilet Club was the place where members of high society took their dogs to be groomed, and the parlour did not underestimate their clients’ love of their animals. Their services included manicures by a resident canine chiropodist, the option of coloured powders for the dogs’ coats, and coat conditioning with egg yolk shampoos.
      In 1900, an article entitled “A Dogs’ Toilet Club” was featured in The Royal Magazine.

    • The trend of bedecking one’s pet in human attire was probably more popular back then than it is today. 

      A well-appointed Poodle at the turn of the 19th century needed an extensive wardrobe that included shirts and suits – both formal and day wear. It also had to have evening outfits, cloaks for cooler weather, and casual wear. 

      Of course, no well-dressed Poodle could be seen without a full complement of jewellery which came in the form of encrusted dog collars and leads as well as tiaras and other headgear.

      There was also a celebrity groomer by the name of R.W. Brown who pleased his clients with his ingenuity and creativity. He was sought after as he had developed the art of clipping patterns and scripting into Poodles’ coats. His clients ordered grooming that included family crests, monograms, and other designs.

      Of course, no well-dressed Poodle could be seen without a full complement of jewellery which came in the form of encrusted dog collars and leads as well as tiaras and other headgear.

      There was also a celebrity groomer by the name of R.W. Brown who pleased his clients with his ingenuity and creativity. He was sought after as he had developed the art of clipping patterns and scripting into Poodles’ coats. His clients ordered grooming that included family crests, monograms, and other designs.
    • 1930's
      In the early part of the 20th century, establishments like the Dogs’ Toilet Club were clearly the exception rather than the rule. The grooming parlour business did expand a little, but most of the grooming was still done privately, by the dogs’ owners or their employees.

      Although there seems to have been very little recorded growth of the dog parlour business, there must have been a steady trade, at least in England. By the 1930s, grooming parlours were becoming more common, but by all accounts, they were small operations with rudimentary equipment.

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • As the size of electronic components grew smaller and the equipment became lighter and quieter, it became more and more adaptable to use in the grooming of pets.

  • History of Dog Grooming: Lesson Summary

  • As you can see from this module, the art of dog grooming probably goes back to when man first domesticated dogs. It was likely initially used for working animals, but it could not have been long before dogs became pets as well. 

    The need for grooming clearly evolved through the need to ensure that the dogs were not injured or hampered in their work by excessively matted and tangled coats. 

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • It was probably also deemed necessary to prevent the dog from smelling bad and harbouring fleas, ticks, and parasites which could have brought the disease into the household.

    Pet grooming today is a growth industry, driven by the fact that pets are more and more regarded as necessary additions to people’s lives and are thought to deserve the best care their owners can afford.

  • It was probably also deemed necessary to prevent the dog from smelling bad and harbouring fleas, ticks, and parasites which could have brought the disease into the household.

    Pet grooming today is a growth industry, driven by the fact that pets are more and more regarded as necessary additions to people’s lives and are thought to deserve the best care their owners can afford.

  • Anatomy and Health in Dogs

  • After completing this module you will be able to:
    • Describe the anatomy of dogs
    • Detail their basic health and how to maintain it
    • Elaborate on the different types of parasites that effect dogs – external and internal
    • Name the infections that may effect a dog during it's life
    • Highlight various diseases dogs are prone to
    • Detail exactly what Zoonotic diseases are

  • Anatomy of Dogs an Overview 

  • All dogs are predators and their anatomies were all originally suited for hunting.

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • Over the millennia, human interference through selective breeding has adapted some breeds to such an extent that they are no longer capable of hunting. Aside from this, they are still equipped with sensory functions that allow them to see, smell and hear in a way that would equip them well for hunting.

    All dogs have the same anatomical structures, but these differ vastly depending on the breed of dog.

    Because of selective breeding and the many different breeds that have resulted from this, there is more anatomical variety in the domesticated dog species than in any other species on earth.

      If you are familiar with any particular dogs, a sure sign of something amiss is a change in the dog’s energy level. A dog that is usually lively and responsive is not likely to behave in a depressed manner or be snappish unless there is something wrong.

      You can gain an idea of what might be wrong by gently feeling the dog all over. If you detect a sensitive reaction from the stomach or chest area, then it is likely that there is an internal injury or problem to be seen to by a vet. 

      Pain or sensitivity on the limbs could indicate damaged muscle tissue or a problem with the bone; again a matter for the vet to deal with.

  • Mange

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • All dogs have the potential to develop mange and it is quite often a sign that the infected dog’s immune system is under threat from another medical condition. 

    The Demodex parasite lives in the oil glands and hair follicles in the surface of the dog’s skin. The animal’s immune system is usually well capable of keeping the mites under control by not allowing their populations to expand.
  • Mange causes hair loss which usually starts near the muzzle and works its way back along the dog. It causes irritation and itching and if not dealt with, will lead to more problematic skin conditions. Some dogs have slightly weaker immune system than others.

    These animals will be more prone to outbreaks of mange which can occur from when they are puppies. Treatment is usually mild and sometimes it is a case of a slight dietary change. In some cases, no intervention is needed.

  • Anatomy and Health - Lesson Summary

    • People who have pets and people such as pet groomers cannot avoid coming into close contact with their pets.
    • Barring accidents, which can usually be avoided with a little common sense and foresight, the relationship between owner and pet is a very fulfilling one.
    • The transmission of infections and diseases is a very rare occurrence that can be entirely avoided with the correct observation of hygiene and a careful watch on the condition of pets.
    • Any change of temperament or the condition must be referred to a vet for immediate diagnosis.

  • Pre-grooming Health Assessment

  • After completing this module you will be able to:
    • Recognise the importance of a pre-grooming health check
    • Explain why it is vital that your client knows the results of the check
    • Elaborate on how to handle a dog during the check
    • Outline why a checklist is so important
    • Detail where to start and what to look for in the health check

  • Pre-grooming Health Checklist 

  • A pre-grooming health check is vital for several reasons, the most important of which is the health of the dog.

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • Although you will get to know the pets of your regular customers fairly quickly, you must never assume that the dog is in the same state of health that he was in the last time you groomed him.

    By far the best way to complete a health check is to follow a pro-forma list that you fill in for every dog as they arrive. Contents of the list will be dealt with later. 
    This is not an exhaustive list, because, after a little experience 
  • in the field, you may wish to amend it, but it is a good place to start. Two reasons that working with a list is a good idea are first that it leaves nothing to chance and secondly that it leaves you with nothing to remember.

    If you don’t have a list to work from, there will come a time when you are under pressure and you will forget to check a vital detail, or you will forget the details you did check.

  • Getting Started 

  • It won’t take long for you to start developing relationships with both your clients and their dogs. 

    The dogs will come to recognise you because grooming sessions, if done properly, are seen by dogs as petting sessions. 

    They may have a few doubts about being bathed, but the rest should all be happy memories for them. You should be one of their favourite people in the world. 

    The dogs will be happy to see you and will show their excitement. What are you going to do? Let’s think back to the first module and how we learned to handle dogs: calm and assertive.

  • Pre-Grooming Assessment - Lesson Summary

    • The pre-grooming health check is a vital part of the grooming process. If you skip it, you will eventually run into problems that would otherwise have been avoided.
    • Remember to always be thorough in the check-up and don’t hesitate to inform the owner of anything out of the ordinary. 
    • For the dog, the pre-grooming check should be a time of relaxed petting which sets the tone for the rest of the process. If a dog is tense and stressed, it will be more difficult to work with.
    • A relaxed dog won’t resist when you need it to move into different positions for clipping and drying. 
    • Remember the importance of the pre-grooming checklist and make sure that you keep your clients in the loop – they will appreciate the care you take and will become your best source of new business.

  • Coat and Skin Disorders

  • After completing this module you will be able to:
    • Describe how to identify skin disorders and what to do about them
    • Detail how to identify coat disorders and how to treat them
    • Explain exactly what effects a dog's coat
    • List the tools you need for grooming
    • Elaborate on how to work with the different types of coats
    • Detail how to remove knotting and matting

    • As we have seen in previous sections, this entails a holistic approach, and you cannot achieve the best results if the dog has any ailments.

      Although you may be focussed on the dog’s coat and claws, if the dog is suffering from any disease or infection, the lustre you hope to give its coat with good quality shampoos and grooming will not last longer than a day or two. 


      As we have seen in previous sections, this entails a holistic approach, and you cannot achieve the best results if the dog has any ailments.

      Although you may be focussed on the dog’s coat and claws, if the dog is suffering from any disease or infection, the lustre you hope to give its coat with good quality shampoos and grooming will not last longer than a day or two. 
    • Illness will give the dog’s coat a dull look and your efforts will be wasted if the underlying cause is not dealt with.

      Although a dull coat is fairly easy to spot, it is a little more difficult to identify the cause. For instance, the dog may have a dull coat and you notice that it is also suffering from hair loss that seems to be more than just shedding. Your first thought is mange, but there are several other ailments that will cause the same symptoms. They may be suffering from the early stages of scabies.

  • Disorders of the Coat

  • A dog’s coat can provide you with an insight into its physical and mental health.

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • A shiny, healthy coat indicates a well-balanced diet and mentally happy animal. 

    Before looking at what warning signs a dog’s coat can give you, remember that some breeds are regarded as non-shedding. 

    These include, but are not limited to, the Portuguese Water Dog, Poodles, Bichon Frise, Schnauzer, Chinese Crested, and Yorkshire Terrier. 

    If you encounter a non-shedding breed that is showing signs of shedding more than a very limited amount of hair, you need to immediately flag it with the owner.

    The loss of hair will almost certainly be a sign of a skin disorders.

  • The definition of “short haired” in grooming terms is a dog that has hair between half an inch to two inches long.

    • Short haired dogs usually have single coats, but there are those with double coats, like the Labrador Retriever. 

      The brushing method is the same for all short haired dogs.

      The tools you need will be limited to a rubber curry brush and a slicker brush – particularly for dogs with double coats.

      At all times be very gentle with the dog and be careful about how much pressure you apply when brushing. Go for repetition rather than pressure, because heavy pressure will not remove hair faster than moderate pressure and you will risk hurting the dog, especially with the slicker brush.
      Short haired dogs usually have single coats, but there are those with double coats, like the Labrador Retriever.

    • Starting at the dog’s head and working with the direction of the hair, brush the dog gently but firmly until the hair stops coming off. This will most certainly require more than one pass, especially if the dog hasn’t been brushed for a few weeks, which is likely with short-haired breeds.

      Don’t forget to work down the legs to the feet, but be gentle here as many dogs are very wary of allowing people to handle their legs and paws. You must work to a set pattern to be sure that you brush the whole dog and remove as much loose hair as possible before bath time.
      Starting at the dog’s head and working with the direction of the hair, brush the dog gently but firmly until the hair stops coming off. This will most certainly require more than one pass, especially if the dog hasn’t been brushed for a few weeks, which is likely with short-haired breeds.

      Don’t forget to work down the legs to the feet, but be gentle here as many dogs are very wary of allowing people to handle their legs and paws.

      You must work to a set pattern to be sure that you brush the whole dog and remove as much loose hair as possible before bath time.

    • If the dog you are working with has hair at the long end of the scale or a double coat, you will need to use a slicker brush to move fur in the undercoat.

      Once again, care must be taken when using a slicker brush. The dog’s double coat gives it protection against the cold, but it will not protect it against the sharp bristles of a slicker brush. Too much pressure and too much attention on one spot will hurt the dog and scrape the top layer of skin off. This is painful, as it is the same as a bad graze. It will have to heal and will form a scab.

    • METHOD
      Starting at the dog’s head and working with the direction of the hair, brush the dog gently but firmly until the hair stops coming off. This will most certainly require more than one pass, especially if the dog hasn’t been brushed for a few weeks, which is likely with short-haired breeds.

      Don’t forget to work down the legs to the feet, but be gentle here as many dogs are very wary of allowing people to handle their legs and paws. You must work to a set pattern to be sure that you brush the whole dog and remove as much loose hair as possible before bath time.

    • DOUBLE COAT
      If the dog you are working with has hair at the long end of the scale or a double coat, you will need to use a slicker brush to move fur in the undercoat.

      Once again, care must be taken when using a slicker brush. The dog’s double coat gives it protection against the cold, but it will not protect it against the sharp bristles of a slicker brush. Too much pressure and too much attention on one spot will hurt the dog and scrape the top layer of skin off. This is painful, as it is the same as a bad graze. It will have to heal and will form a scab.

Too much pressure and too much attention on one spot will hurt the dog and scrape the top layer of skin off. This is painful, as it is the same as a bad graze. It will have to heal and will form a scab.

      The tools you need will be limited to a rubber curry brush and a slicker brush – particularly for dogs with double coats.

  • Coat and Skin Disorders - Lesson Summary

    • Although dogs can usually be placed into a coat category without too much difficulty, there are crossbreeds that have two distinct hair types. For instance, a Maltese- Pekinese cross will probably have a coat made up of two distinct hair types evenly distributed throughout their coats. This should not cause a problem from the grooming point of view, but for a neat appearance, the dog might have to be clipped more often than a purebred dog, as the different hair types could grow at different rates.
    • Where a dog’s coat cannot be easily categorised, your intuition and experience will be your best guides. A word with the owner about their experience with brushing the dog will also be useful.
    • With the grooming of any dog, remember that patience and a calm, assertive attitude are essential.
    • You must constantly look for ways to up your work rate as you develop a quick, thorough, and gentle working style.
    • Dogs are usually patient, but they can easily become bored and restless, which will make the job more difficult.

  • Starting a Business

  • After completing this course you will be able to:
    • Determine whether or not pet grooming is for you
    • List the avenues open to people wanting to work in the industry
    • Detail how to start your own business
    • Show how you can create a business plan
    • Describe what to look for in a premises

  • The Business of Pet Grooming 

  • The pet grooming business is a relatively new industry.

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • It really only started finding its feet in the early 1950s when the world was recovering from World War II. Pet grooming shops or salons had started gaining popularity in the United Kingdom in the 1920s. 

    These were very much cousins of the back street laundries with minimal equipment and gloomy premises.
  • As the Baby Boom found its feet and the idea that a family needed a pet gained popularity on both sides of the Atlantic, the pet grooming industry started coming to life. It was great fun owning a pet, but people soon realised that looking after a pet was a big commitment. Post-war pet preferences were very much dictated by the breeds starring in the movies and TV series of the late 40s and 50s.

      Maybe it’s that your shop is closed down; maybe it catches fire and all your equipment is lost.

    Considerations

    Let’s take the fire scenario as a practical exercise. Everything is running smoothly when suddenly you receive a phone call telling you that the building has burned down. Ask yourself what happens next. Are you ruined because you didn’t have adequate insurance cover? Or, you thought you had adequate insurance cover, but there is a clause that you didn’t know about and you are only partially covered. The point of the exercise is to look at every eventuality and test your preparedness against what could happen. You have to know that you won’t be ruined if something that could have been foreseen actually happens.

  • FIRE SCENARIO
    ×

    Considerations

    Let’s take the fire scenario as a practical exercise. Everything is running smoothly when suddenly you receive a phone call telling you that the building has burned down. Ask yourself what happens next. Are you ruined because you didn’t have adequate insurance cover? Or, you thought you had adequate insurance cover, but there is a clause that you didn’t know about and you are only partially covered. The point of the exercise is to look at every eventuality and test your preparedness against what could happen. You have to know that you won’t be ruined if something that could have been foreseen actually happens.

  • Starting a Business - Lesson Summary

    • Starting a new business is no mean feat. You will have to have a lot of courage and the determination to succeed. 
    • A lot will depend on your skills, but in setting up shop, you must leave as little as possible to chance.
    • The business plan is an essential element. It’s not an iron-clad guarantee of success, but not having one will contribute to your failure; having one will contribute to your success. 
    • The business plan is like a road map that you can consult to see where you are and if things are going according to plan. If you don’t have that plan, you will set yourself up for failure.
    • Once you have got your business going, you have to keep driving yourself and the business. One sure way of doing this is to always be learning and looking for new solutions to old problems.
    • Another essential aspect of business today is to be involved with the community that supports your business. If you can show that you give back to the community in a meaningful way, the community will respond accordingly. 
    • An example of involvement in your community would be to offer your services to a local dog rescue project and be visible in their operations.

  • Animal Training

  • After completing this module you will be able to:
    • Summarize how to train animals to enjoy bath time
    • List the step-by-step approach to bath time
    • Explain how to prepare a fearful dog for bathing
    • Elaborate on the sequence of bathing activities
    • Describe why dogs may dislike bathing
    • Outline why dogs may fear other aspects of grooming

  • Profit and Loss

  • Being the owner of a pet grooming salon means that you need to have the optimum number of clients coming through your doors every day. You will have to calculate how many dogs you can groom in an eight or nine hour period and then plan your booking schedule and staff requirements around that.

    You have to balance your love of animals and the love of what you do against the truth behind the old cliché “Time is money”. If you don’t make a profit at the end of the day, you will be out of business in a matter of a few months.

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • Basics of Bathing

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • The question from the grooming parlour owner’s perspective is: How do we get all dogs to love bathing? The answer is patience and a planned approach to reaching a defined goal. 

    How to get all dogs that come in for grooming to love every aspect of the process? A calm, assertive, and gentle approach to the grooming process that leaves the dog thinking the whole thing is one long petting session.

  • Clippers and Noise

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • Igor will probably handle the grooming process like a champion. For a short haired dog, there is very little in the way of clipping and fan assisted or dryer assisted drying to be done. Animals with curly, medium, and long coats are the ones who will require drying and clipping, and in the summer months, shaving. 

    As soon as you use machines in the vicinity of dogs, there are likely to be dogs that react badly to the clippers or the dryers or to anything that buzzes. Once again, their phobia is probably caused by prior association. They will be remembering a time when something that made a similar sound caused them harm or they were somehow made to associate the sound with fear.

  • Animal Training - Lesson Summary

  • The bath is probably the biggest issue that dogs will have. The problem stems from puppyhood when owners were unaware that they needed to familiarise their new pet with the process of bathing. As a result, when the puppy was faced with a strange situation for the first time, he reacted as one would expect and baulked at the prospect of being bathed.

  • With the correct approach, you will be able to cure any dog of virtually any phobia. Always remember that dogs want to please their human handler, and that treats and praise are signs to the dog that he is doing the right thing. To ensure that he gets more treats, the dog will repeat the behaviour.

  • It is possible to rid a dog of a phobia to such a degree that what was once their nemesis becomes their favourite thing instead. Patience and repetition will ultimately win the day.
